required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Tolerability of a Novel Malathion Formulation in Children Age 6-24 Months With Head Lice
clinical_study.official_title: Phase II, Multi-Center, Open-Label, Safety and Tolerance Study of a Novel Malathion Formulation in Infants and Toddlers With Pediculosis Capitis

brief_summary.textblock:
In a previous phase II study, the safety and efficacy of a novel formulation of malathion 0.5% was evaluated in patients 2 years of age and older. Based on the results of that study, this formulation is currently in a phase III study for that population.
The current study will use blood markers and clinical evaluations to determine the safety and tolerability of this formulation when used in children 6-24 months of age.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With a Change in Cholinesterase Level at 1 Hour (Day 0).
primary_outcome.description: Each patient (aged 6 - 24 months) was assessed at 1 hour (Day 0). The mean percent change (reduction) in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity from baseline to 1 hr after application was calculated and accompanied by 95% confidence intervals. If the half-widths of the derived confidence intervals are sufficiently narrow, it will demonstrate that any observed reductions in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity fall within established safety guidelines. Concentration of RBC-cholinesterase (RBC-ChE) and plasma cholinesterase were obtained at baseline, at 1 hr (Day 0) and at 24 hrs (Day 1) after the application of the treatment. Mean percent change (reduction) = (Post treatment value - Baseline)/ Baseline x100.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With a Change in Cholinesterase Level at 24 Hrs (1 Day).
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 24 hrs (1 day)
primary_outcome.description: Each patient was assessed at Day 1 and the mean percent reduction in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity from baseline to 24 hr after application was calculated and accompanied by 95% confidence intervals. Concentration of RBC-cholinesterase (RBC-ChE) and plasma cholinesterase were obtained at baseline, at 1 hr (Day 0) and at 24 hrs (Day 1) after the application of the treatment. Mean percent reduction = (Post treatment value - Baseline)/ Baseline x100.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With the Clinical Evidence of Cholinesterase Inhibition
primary_outcome.description: Participants with any of the following symptoms of cholinesterase inhibition as numbered below were considered to have Clinical evidence of cholinesterase inhibition. Abnormal heart rate. Diarrhea or abdominal cramps. Inappropriate sweating. Pupillary miosis (constriction). Respiratory difficulty such as chest tightness or wheezing. One participant had wheezing as medical history which continued without increase in severity throughout the treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With the Clinical Evidence of Cholinesterase Inhibition
primary_outcome.description: Participants with any of the following symptoms of cholinesterase inhibition as numbered below were considered to have Clinical evidence cholinesterase inhibition : Abnormal heart rate. Diarrhea or abdominal cramps. Inappropriate sweating. Pupillary miosis (constriction). Respiratory difficulty such as chest tightness or wheezing. One participants had wheezing as medical history which continued without increase in severity throughout the treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants With the Clinical Evidence of Cholinesterase Inhibition
primary_outcome.description: Participants with any of the following symptoms of cholinesterase inhibition as numbered below were considered to have Clinical evidence of cholinesterase inhibition : Abnormal heart rate. Diarrhea or abdominal cramps. Inappropriate sweating. Pupillary miosis (constriction). Respiratory difficulty such as chest tightness or wheezing. One participants had wheezing as medical history which continued without increase in severity throughout the treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Participants Clinically Cured of Head Lice 14 Days After Last Treatment
primary_outcome.description: No live lice (including adults and nymphs) and nits at Day 7±1 and final lice assessment on either Day 14 (subjects not requiring retreatment) or Day 21 (for retreated subjects).

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of the Local Safety of Malathion Gel, 0.5% Based Upon Reported Adverse Events and Observed Scalp Reactions.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants were followed for a minimum of 14 days (1 treatment) and a maximum of 21 days (2 treatments)
secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the safety of Malathion Gel, 0.5% based upon reported adverse events and observed scalp reactions. Additional safety assessments included eye Irritation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Confirmed active head lice infestation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergy to pediculicides or hair care products
- Scalp conditions other than head lice
- Previous head lice treatment within the past 4 weeks
- Current antibiotic treatment

results_reference.citation: Meinking TL, Vicaria M, Eyerdam DH, Villar ME, Reyna S, Suarez G. A randomized, investigator-blinded, time-ranging study of the comparative efficacy of 0.5% malathion gel versus Ovide Lotion (0.5% malathion) or Nix Crème Rinse (1% permethrin) used as labeled, for the treatment of head lice. Pediatr Dermatol. 2007 Jul-Aug;24(4):405-11.

group.title: Malathion Gel 0.5% Treatment Arm
group.description: Malathion Gel 0.5% treatment MALG (Malathion Gel 0.5%) Treatment: MALG applied for 30 minutes

group.title: MALG Treatment Arm
group.description: MALG treatment MALG (malathion) Treatment: MALG applied for 30 minutes

class.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Participants With a Change in Cholinesterase Level at 1 Hour (Day 0).
outcome.description: Each patient (aged 6 – 24 months) was assessed at 1 hour (Day 0). The mean percent change (reduction) in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity from baseline to 1 hr after application was calculated and accompanied by 95% confidence intervals. If the half-widths of the derived confidence intervals are sufficiently narrow, it will demonstrate that any observed reductions in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity fall within established safety guidelines. Concentration of RBC-cholinesterase (RBC-ChE) and plasma cholinesterase were obtained at baseline, at 1 hr (Day 0) and at 24 hrs (Day 1) after the application of the treatment. Mean percent change (reduction) = (Post treatment value – Baseline)/ Baseline x100.
outcome.population: 10 subjects with obtained blood sample. subject 01-003: Study coordinator was unable to obtain blood sample post treatment at Visit 1, Day 0. subject 01-004: At Visit 1 Day 0 (post treatment), Blood sample could not be obtained even after two attempts.

group.title: MALG (Malathion Gel, 0.5% )Treatment Arm
group.description: MALG (Malathion Gel, 0.5% ) treatment MALG (Malathion Gel, 0.5% ) Treatment: MALG applied for 30 minutes Two subjects had out of range RBC cholinesterase values. One subject had out of range (low) value at baseline and One subject had out of range (low) value 1 h post treatment. Both these values were considered to be not clinically significant by the investigator.

outcome.title: Participants With a Change in Cholinesterase Level at 24 Hrs (1 Day).
outcome.description: Each patient was assessed at Day 1 and the mean percent reduction in plasma and RBC cholinesterase activity from baseline to 24 hr after application was calculated and accompanied by 95% confidence intervals. Concentration of RBC-cholinesterase (RBC-ChE) and plasma cholinesterase were obtained at baseline, at 1 hr (Day 0) and at 24 hrs (Day 1) after the application of the treatment. Mean percent reduction = (Post treatment value – Baseline)/ Baseline x100.
outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 24 hrs (1 day)
outcome.population: 11 subjects with obtained blood sample. subject 01-004: At Visit 2, Day 1 Lab could not perform testing due to sample not suitable for testing. Because only 2ml blood was able to collected after multiple attempts.

outcome.title: Evaluation of the Local Safety of Malathion Gel, 0.5% Based Upon Reported Adverse Events and Observed Scalp Reactions.
outcome.description: To evaluate the safety of Malathion Gel, 0.5% based upon reported adverse events and observed scalp reactions. Additional safety assessments included eye Irritation.
outcome.time_frame: Participants were followed for a minimum of 14 days (1 treatment) and a maximum of 21 days (2 treatments)
outcome.population: A total of 12 subjects were enrolled. All of them used the study drug for at least one dose of the treatment. At Day 0 the study drug was to be used. At Day 7 if subject presented with live lice they were provided a second treatment. The subjects may used it for 1 (for subjects not requiring retreatment) or 2 (for retreated subjects).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
